subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: I have been on vacation and am trying to catch up with what s been going on. I agree with Moira.  I use all three sounds:  Awl, Ah and On.  In fact, I really
messageBody:
I have been on vacation and am trying to catch up with what's been going on.

I agree with Moira.  I use all three sounds:  Awl, Ah and On.  In fact, I really don't understand what some people mean when they say they can't hear the difference between Awl and On.  It strikes me in a similar way as if they said they can't distinguish between blue and green.  Obviously,  the boundary between the two colors is somewhat ambiguous, but most of us have a clear enough idea of what blue is versus what green is.

I have thought that those who say they can't hear the difference actually just means they don't use the Awl sound, i.e. they pronounce words such as "all" with the On sound.  I expect that they can hear the difference if they listen closely to someone pronouncing Awl versus On even if it is not a distinction they make in their own speech. 

This whole thread seems to have started as a method to enable a dictionary to have all spelling variants placed together alphabetically.  Rather than throwing out a phoneme that many of us feel quite strongly about, it makes more sense to me that if there is a variant spelling that will not be next to the others simply put in a note directing the reader to the other spelling as in:  "see also: _______."

I also feel strongly about the continued availability of "Wh".  I am sure that those who don't use it don't miss it, but I can assure you reading the QS news with nary a "wh" to be seen is noticed by me every time I come across a word where I would use it.  I actually seem more aware of its absence in writing than I am in hearing others who don't use "wh" in their speech.

Paige

Moira O'Brien wrote:

As a speaker of RP, I can't agree to the merger of Awl Ah and On.  My pronunciation makes full use of all three as distinct sounds.  
It also does with Wool & Ooze but losing one of those two would not be much of a hardship.  
The distinction between those sounds is quite small and not significant and is very much like the different sounds of Schwa.

Moira
